raw_text:
Williams battles to Aussie title
 
 Serena Williams staged a remarkable recovery to beat Lindsay Davenport and win her second Australian Open title.
 
 The 2003 champion claimed her seventh Grand Slam title, and her first since Wimbledon in 2003, 2-6 6-3 6-0. Williams had looked close to quitting with a rib injury when she left the court for treatment after five games. She quickly dropped the first set but from 3-3 in the second found another gear as Davenport's game collapsed, allowing Williams to take the title. Williams later explained her injury problem, saying it was the result of lunging for a ball early in the first set. "Lindsay had me on the run out wide on my backhand and my back went but eventually I was able to come back, thank goodness," she said. Davenport paid tribute to Williams, saying: "She's had a tough couple of years and she's come back like a champion."
 
 The 23-year-old former world number one was in desperate trouble in the early stages as the injury hampered her service action. Davenport took advantage to race through the opening set and held six break points in game five of the second. "I kept thinking to myself 'I'm not losing this game," said Williams afterwards. "'I don't care if my arm falls off, I'm not losing this game'. And I guess that's what happened. "I didn't want to lose that particular game because it would have given her a lot of momentum, and a lot of confidence." Despite letting the break points slip away Davenport looked comfortable enough at 3-3, but from 40-0 up she just folded. Williams won nine consecutive points for the set and powered through the decider as a lacklustre Davenport looked to have run out of energy after a gruelling two weeks. "I felt like I was playing well and in control pretty much of the match," said Davenport. "Then I just had that horrible lapse, I think serving up 40-0, and made a few errors and opened up the door for her and she just kept going through it. "At the end I think I was a little bit fatigued but she took advantage of it and kept going - she's a great frontrunner when she gets going."
llama3.2:1b: Serena Williams won her second Australian Open title, defeating Lindsay Davenport 2-6, 6-3, 6-0.
Williams had a remarkable recovery from a rib injury that forced her to leave the court for treatment after five games in the first set.
She lost the first game but rallied with nine consecutive points in the second and two more sets, ultimately winning 9-7 in the decisive set.
llama3.2:3b: Serena Williams staged a remarkable recovery to beat Lindsay Davenport 2-6, 6-3, 6-0 in the Australian Open final.
Williams had a rib injury that forced her to leave the court for treatment after five games but quickly regained form in the second set.
Davenport took advantage of Williams' early struggles to hold six break points in game five but eventually collapsed, allowing Williams to take the title.

Williams suffered a rib injury early in the match that hampered her play but she recovered to win the match after fighting back from a deficit.
Davenport praised Williams' comeback and resilience.

Williams suffered a rib injury in the first set after finishing on court five, but quickly adapted to play at a higher level.
She had a tough day as she lost five games and was held scoreless for four sets.
Her recovery led to her winning the tournament, while Davenport praised Williams' determination to prove herself.

Williams suffered from an injury problem early in the match but regained momentum later and defeated Davenport 4-6, 6-3, 7-5.

Despite early trouble due to an injury affecting her service action, Williams held serve at 3-3 and won nine consecutive points in the second set.
She took control of the third set as Davenport's energy flagged after two weeks of competition.
Williams expressed determination not to lose that game, while Davenport acknowledged a lapse in concentration cost her match.
opencoder:1.5b: Williams battles to Aussie title, The 2003 champion claimed her seventh Grand Slam title, and her first since Wimbledon in the second Australian Open title.
The 23-year-old former world number one was in serious need of treatment due to a rib injury that prevented her service action.
Despite her injuries, Davenport took advantage of race through the opening set and held six break points in game five.
However, from there she looked comfortable enough at 3-3, but continued power play as a lacklustre Davenport looked to have run out of energy after a grueling two weeks.
smollm:1.7b: Williams battled to Aussie title in 2003, winning seven Grand Slam titles.
Her recovery from a rib injury in 2003 was crucial as she looked to win her second Australian Open title.
She won the first set but lost the second set due to Lindsay Davenport's poor service action.
Williams' injury problem was the result of lunging for a ball early in the first set, which led to her arm falling off and causing her to miss several shots.
Despite this setback, she quickly dropped the first set and found another gear as Davenport's game collapsed.
She later explained that her injury problem was due to the fact that she had been running out of energy after a gruelling two weeks.
Williams' recovery from her injury allowed her to win the second Australian Open title in 2003, which was her seventh Grand Slam title.
She looked closely to have beaten Lindsay Davenport and won her first Australian Open title since Wimbledon in 2003.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Serena Williams successfully reached an Australian Open title in 2003 as her seventh Grand Slam victory since Wimbledon in 2003.
She claimed her second Australian Open title, defeating Lindsay Davenport 6-0 6-3 2-6 on a thrilling opening set.
Williams had struggled with a rib injury and briefly left the court, but she quickly recovered, allowing her to secure the title.
Williams explained her injury as related to early service, where Davenport's game collapsed, enabling her victory in set two.
Davenport expressed gratitude for Williams' resilience and determination during a tough year.
Williams' performance against Davenport was notable for her quick recovery from her injury and her ability to adapt under pressure.
tinyllama:1.1b: After struggling in the early stages, Serena Williams fought back to win her second Australian Open title over Lindsey Dementport by recovering from a set down to beat her opponent's injury and come back with a vengeance in the final.

Despite facing a back issue at 3-3, Williams quickly regained her composure and played an impressive game against Dementport, winning nine consecutive points for the set after falling behind 2-0 in the second.

The injured player went on to lose four games in the decider and ultimately lost out to the champion, but praised her opponent's performance as a "tough lady" who fought back despite being tired and showing great stamina.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Williams had an unfortunate turn in her recovery from a rib injury, but managed to seize victory against the formidable Lindsay Davenport.
The match was marked by intense pressure from both players who could not afford to make any mistakes or face defeat.
Williams, with her trademark resilience and strong serve, won the first set but was unable to maintain this level of play in the second.
This allowed Davenport to rally back into the game, only to be overwhelmed by the veteran's powerful ground strokes and superior squandered chances.
Williams' physical fitness, coupled with her excellent stamina, enabled her to overcome Davenport's momentum and dominate the match in the crucial second set.
In the end, Williams emerged victorious, winning her first Australian Open title since 2003.
phi:2.7b: Serena Williams defeated Lindsay Davenport in their Australian Open final to win her seventh Grand Slam title, her first since Wimbledon in 2003.
The 2003 champion had an injury that made her drop the first set but managed to recover and take the title after dropping only two games in the second set.
The match was close for both players until Williams took control in game five of the second set with six break points.
Despite Davenport's attempts to fight back, Williams came out victorious at 6-0.
The 23-year-old former world number one said she had lost confidence and momentum early on but managed to turn things around by staying focused.

After losing six break points in game five of the second set, Williams didn't want to lose the game that would have given momentum to her opponent.

Struggling with a rib injury early in the match, Williams left the court for treatment and initially lost the first set.
However, from 3-3 in the second set, she found her rhythm as Davenport's game faltered.
Williams credited her determination for turning the match around, refusing to lose a crucial game despite her injury.
Davenport, who had dominated early, admitted to a lapse in concentration and fatigue, allowing Williams to seize control and power through the final set.
She praised Williams for her resilience and ability to capitalize on momentum.

Despite facing six break points in game five, Williams ultimately found momentum and control in the final set.

granite3.1-dense:2b: Serena Williams, the 2003 Australian Open champion, secured her seventh Grand Slam title and first since Wimbledon 2003, overcoming a ribs injury that affected her serve.
She trailed 2-6 in the first set but rebounded to win 6-3, 6-0 against Lindsay Davenport.
The injury occurred when Williams lunged for a ball during the first set.
Despite early setbacks and fatigue, Williams showed resilience, rallying from a 40-0 deficit in game five of the second set to secure nine consecutive points and win the set.
Davenport acknowledged Williams' strong performance, noting her champion spirit following a challenging couple of years.
